title: 105_hr3035
content: The Act is titled the "National Drought Policy Act of 1998" and includes findings related to drought. Congress finds that the United States suffers economic and environmental losses from severe regional droughts, lacking a coordinated Federal strategy to respond. Historically, droughts of national consequences are addressed through special legislation rather than a systematic process. There is a growing need for preparedness, mitigation, and risk management at the Federal level for drought and other natural disasters. Multiple Federal agencies play a role in predicting, forecasting, and monitoring drought conditions. The President should appoint an advisory commission to provide advice on creating an integrated Federal policy for drought preparedness, mitigation, response, and recovery. Establishment of Commission. The National Drought Policy Commission is established with 16 members including various government officials. The National Drought Policy Commission is established with 16 members including government officials nominated by different associations and appointed by the President and Secretaries of Agriculture, Interior, and Army. The National Drought Policy Commission consists of 16 members representing various interest groups. Appointments must be made within 60 days of the Act's enactment, with members serving for the Commission's duration. Vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed and will meet at the chair's discretion. A majority of members constitutes a quorum for meetings. The National Drought Policy Commission consists of 16 members representing various interest groups. A majority of members constitutes a quorum for meetings, and a lesser number can hold hearings. The Commission will select a vice chair from members who are not Federal officers or employees. The National Drought Policy Commission consists of 16 members representing various interest groups. A majority of members constitutes a quorum for meetings, and a lesser number can hold hearings. The Commission will select a vice chair from members who are not Federal officers or employees. SEC. 4. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The National Drought Policy Commission is tasked with conducting a study and submitting a report on national drought policy. This includes determining needs at various levels, reviewing existing laws and programs, and collaborating with relevant entities. The National Drought Policy Commission collaborates with relevant entities to consider regional drought initiatives and their application at the national level. It makes recommendations on integrating Federal drought laws with State, local, and tribal programs into a comprehensive national policy. Additionally, it suggests improving public awareness of drought mitigation and prevention, and developing a coordinated approach involving governmental and nongovernmental entities. The National Drought Policy Commission is tasked with submitting a report to the President and Congress within 18 months of the Act's enactment. The report will contain findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislation and administrative actions. Approval of the report requires unanimous consent or majority vote. Those voting against the report must submit dissenting views. The Commission has the power to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, use postal services, and accept gifts. Commission personnel matters are also addressed. Members of the Commission are not compensated unless they are federal government officers or employees, who will receive their regular compensation. They are allowed travel expenses while on Commission business. Federal government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement. The Secretary of Agriculture provides financial, administrative, and staff support services for the Commission without interrupting civil service status or privilege. The Commission will terminate 90 days after submitting its report under section 4.
